items.title: One Battle After Another, Sinners, Adolescence and more nominated for 2026 Golden Globe Awards
items.summary_auto: One Battle After Another, Hamnet, Sinners and other big films are all tipped for a number of nominations at the 83rd Golden Globes. The award show will also have a brand new category for podcasting this year.

items.title: Ukraine's Zelenskyy meets with EU, NATO leaders after talks with U.S. on revised peace plan
items.summary_auto: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was meeting with British, French and German leaders in London on Monday, followed by scheduled NATO-hosted talks, rallying allies for support as the United States increases pressure on Kyiv to agree to a proposed peace deal with Russia.

items.title: Foreign workers accuse hotelier with history of labour violations of taking advantage of them in Sask., Man.
items.summary_auto: A man from Mexico says he toiled long hours, seven days a week, for nearly a year without proper pay for a hotel chain that he says took advantage of him and others.

items.title: NHL Heritage Classic's 2026 return to Winnipeg will be 'great for the city,' fans say
items.summary_auto: The NHL's Heritage Classic is returning to Winnipeg next year and some local sports fans — including a former Jets goalie — say the outdoor hockey spectacle will draw a lot of positive attention to the city.

items.title: Thailand launches airstrikes along border with Cambodia after deadly clashes
items.summary_auto: Thailand launched airstrikes along the disputed border with Cambodia on Monday as both sides accused the other of breaking a ceasefire that halted fighting earlier this year.

items.title: Chinese ex-spy opens up about targeting dissident who died mysteriously in B.C.
As fraud in Ontario continues to climb, police are laying fewer charges — and courts are tossing the majority
items.summary_auto: CBC News reviewed the latest three years of fraud statistics released since its investigative series The Cost of Fraud revealed that only a fraction of fraud cases were making it through Ontario’s justice system a few years ago. The new numbers from Statistics Canada show the problem has only gotten worse, and have some experts pointing to alternative solutions to stem the flow of fraud.

items.title: Ontario jails set to hit overcrowding record as bail reform looms, data shows
items.summary_auto: Ontario jails are heading toward a record year for overcrowding, remand populations and lockdowns just as politicians debate bail reforms that could lead to a further influx of accused behind bars, data analyzed by CBC News reveals.

items.title: Majority of Ontario fraud cases tossed since 2020 due to limited resources: Crowns’ association
items.summary_auto: CBC News reviewed the latest three years of fraud statistics released since its investigative series The Cost of Fraud revealed that only a fraction of fraud cases were making it through Ontario’s justice system a few years ago. The new numbers from Statistics Canada show the problem has only gotten worse, and have some experts pointing to alternative solutions to stem the flow of fraud.

items.title: A Chinese dissident died suddenly in B.C. This ex-spy who snooped on him says it may not have been an accident
items.summary_auto: A former spy for China's security services has provided thousands of text and voice messages, as well as financial documents, to journalists. Among the records: instructions from his bosses to snoop on an artist who fled to Canada.

items.title: Bill 2 puts Montreal clinic serving sexual assault victims at risk of closure
items.summary_auto: A family clinic in downtown Montreal that treats over 10,000 patients could close its doors due to Bill 2, a controversial law that ties doctors' salaries to key performance indicators. Dr. Andrée Vincent says Clinique Medic Elle, which also serves as a centre for victims of sexual assault, could lose some of its doctors. She and her colleagues are already receiving job offers from outside the province.

items.title: Why Jeff Kinney draws from his childhood to create the smash 'Wimpy Kid' series
items.summary_auto: With more than "300 million copies sold," American creator Jeff Kinney's cheeky Diary of a Wimpy Kid series is a huge hit. He stopped by The Next Chapter to discuss the series and the latest book, Partypooper.

items.title: #TheMoment students reunited after losing their N.L. school to wildfires
items.summary_auto: Jackie King, Jace Hogan and Allison Slade tell The National about the moment students from Cabot Academy in Conception Bay, N.L., reunited for the holidays after their school burned down in the summer.

items.title: Bethlehem Christmas tree lit up for first time since start of Gaza war
items.summary_auto: Hundreds of people gathered in Bethlehem's Manger Square to watch the lighting of a Christmas tree, two years after all public celebrations for the holiday were cancelled due to the war in Gaza.

items.title: Trump lauds 'good relationship' with Carney but won't say if they'll restart trade talks
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump spoke highly of Canada on Sunday. But when asked if he would restart trade talks with his northern neighbour, he replied with a vague, "We'll see."

items.title: Donald Trump hosting Kennedy Center Honors recognizing Stallone, Kiss, Gaynor and others
Is Canada’s hockey culture broken?
items.summary_auto: Questioning hockey culture in Canada can be controversial, but it’s something award-winning author and sports journalist Rick Westhead doesn’t shy away from. In conversation with The National’s Ian Hanomansing, he lays out what he uncovered for his new book We Breed Lions and the impact he hopes it has on the sport.

items.title: Montreal Victoire defeats Toronto Sceptres 3-1, land second straight win
items.summary_auto: Ann-Renée Desbiens made 21 saves, including 11 in the third period, as the Montreal Victoire defeated the Toronto Sceptres 3-1 in Professional Women's Hockey League action Sunday afternoon at Place Bell in Laval, Que.

items.title: Thousands of Santas dash through Liverpool streets for charity
items.summary_auto: Liverpool's annual Santa Dash made spirits bright on Sunday as thousands of runners dressed as Santa Claus took to the streets of the English city for the five-kilometre festive fun run. Participants are encouraged to raise money for local charities as part of the event, which began in 2004.

items.title: Fatal blaze in Fort William First Nation is 4th trailer fire in Thunder Bay, Ont., district in a week
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s Office of the Fire Marshal is investigating a fatal blaze in Fort William First Nation, which marks the fourth trailer fire in the Thunder Bay district within a week. Here's what we know about the recent incidents.

items.title: Trump's new security strategy aligns with Russia's interests, Kremlin says
items.summary_auto: The Kremlin on Sunday welcomed U.S. President Donald Trump's new national security strategy and said it largely accorded with Russia's own perceptions, the first time that Moscow has so fulsomely praised such a document from its former Cold War foe.
